title: Joe Frickleton
text:
Joe Frickleton (c. 1935 – 14 December 2020) was a Scottish professional <a href="association%20football">football</a> player and manager, active primarily in South Africa
Playing career.
Frickleton, who played as a <a href="wing%20half">wing half</a>, played youth with <a href="Clydebank%20Juniors%20F.C.">Clydebank Juniors</a>, before turning professional with <a href="East%20Stirlingshire%20F.C.">East Stirlingshire</a>, where he made 107 appearances in the <a href="Scottish%20Football%20League">Scottish Football League</a> between 1959 and 1964.
He then moved to South Africa to play with <a href="Highlands%20Park%20FC">Highlands Park</a>, where he won three <a href="National%20Football%20League%20%28South%20Africa%29">national championships</a>.
Coaching career.
After his playing days were over, Frickleton remained in South Africa, and trained as a football manager. His first job was at former club <a href="Highlands%20Park%20FC">Highlands Park</a> in 1974. After a season spent with <a href="Lusitano%20F.C.%20%28South%20Africa%29">Lusitano</a>, Frickleton returned to Highlands Park until it was sold in 1983. He later won four trophies with <a href="Kaizer%20Chiefs%20F.C.">Kaizer Chiefs</a> in 1984, before winning the <a href="CAF%20Champions%20League">Champions Cup</a> with <a href="Orlando%20Pirates%20FC">Orlando Pirates</a> in 1995.
Later life and death.
He was hospitalised in May 2020 in <a href="Cape%20Town">Cape Town</a> due to ill health. His death was reported on 15 December 2020.
